chapter.title: In The Beginning
chapter.para: The whole purpose of ooDialog is to enable ooRexx developers to provide users with a GUI (graphical user interface). A GUI is a collection of windows. Each window contains a number of controls, such as entry fields, push buttons, list boxes, and so forth. The user keys data into controls (e.g. types into an entry field) or manipulates controls with a mouse (e.g. selects an item in a listbox). Some of these actions invoke application code which in turn makes some change to the window, causes some other action such as data access, or both.
Now, there are three areas of concern in designing an ooDialog application:

listitem.para: Designing the appearance of the window
Designing the desired user interactions with the window
Designing the code that implements both appearance and interactions

chapter.para: And there are three corresponding areas of implementation concern:

listitem.para: Implementing the actions requested by users of a window
Providing the results of those actions to the user on the window.

chapter.para: This document does not pretend to be a guide to best practice in the areas of design, although it tries to conform with good design principles. However, this document does aim to familiarise readers with the essentials of ooDialog application implementation.

So, before starting the first exercise, please make sure that you have downloaded and installed the latest versions of ooRexx and also ooDialog. Please also run one or more of the samples in ooRexx Samples --> ooDialog to ensure that your installation is properly completed.

section.title: Getting Started
section.para: The first exercise creates and displays a blank window with the title "Hello World!". Try it - find "Exercise01.rex" in the "Sample Code\Exercise01" folder, and double-click it. You should see this:

The Command Prompt window that appears with the "Hello World" window is irrelevant, and later we'll find out how to dispense with it. But now, let's look at the "Hello World" code (excluding the comments that are in the file):

listitem.para:
First, the program that does the work :
dlg = .MyDialog~new dlg~execute("SHOWTOP", IDI_DLG_OOREXX)
The first statement creates an instance of the class MyDialog, and assigns the instance to the variable dlg (the MyDialog class is defined in the third part of the code). The second statement invokes the execute method of MyDialog, and it is this that displays the window.
Note that the usual naming conventions are observed: upper camel case for classes (e.g. MyDialogand lower camel case for variables (including of course instance variables - e.g. dlg).

Second, the directive to ooRexx to use ooDialog:
::requires "ooDialog.cls"
This one directive allows all the classes defined by ooDialog (including UserDialog) to be accessible to our program. If this statement is absent, then the following error appears on the initiating comand prompt:
16 *-* ::class 'MyDialog' subclass UserDialog Error 98 running ... Exercise01\Exercise01.rex line 16: Execution error Error 98.909: Class "USERDIALOG" not found
Note that it's UserDialog (see next bullet) that's not found. This is because the ::requires ooDialog.cls statement not only says we're using ooDialog, but also provides access to all the classes provided by ooDialog. Later, we'll see a further use for the ::requires directive.

Finally, there's the definition of the class MyDialog:
::class MyDialog subclass UserDialog ::method init forward class (super) continue self~create(30, 30, 257, 123, "Hello World", "CENTER")
The first line defines a class called MyDialog as a subclass of the ooDialog-provided class UserDialog
See Chapter 7 of the ooDialog Reference for full details. Among other things, UserDialog enables the programmer to define the window layout in code. This can get cumbersome in more advanced dialogs, and later we'll meet a simpler way of defining a more realistic window layout.

The second line defines the init method, and the third line calls the superclass which does the heavy work of creating the window.
See Chapter 3 of the ooDialog Reference manual. This is supplemented by the last line, where the create message is sent to self and hence to UserDialog. This method defines the "template" to be used - that is, the layout of the window - in this case the position and size of the "Hello World" window, as well as the text to be dispayed in the window's title bar.
See Chapter 7 of the Windows ooDialog Reference.

Finally, this instance of the MyDialog class having been set up properly, the window is actually surfaced (made visible) by the execute message (handled by MyDialog's superclass) sent by the second statement in the first part of the program (see above).
